Fields.DialogueText: Officers, ready for combat! This is going to be a hard one, but do not hesitate to act!
@BATTLE
Mind if I come in?
It is your mess, Kapitän. Is it the music? I can stop the phonograph if you find it foreboding.
Foreboding isn't the word I'd have chosen. Poignant, perhaps?
Have you seen Tristan und Isolde?

Fields.MenuText: The one where the fat lady sings at the end?
Can't say that I have.
It's been a while, but yes.

Fields.DialogueText: ... Not quite, Kapitän. You're thinking of Brünnhilde's aria at the ending of Götterdammerung.
You should, Kapitän. It is quite... exhilarating. One of the most sensuous works to have come out of Germany.
I'm glad we have yet one more thing in common, Kapitän.
This is the prelude overture. It helps me find serenity when it is in short supply.
Those charts on the table have anything to do with what's making it elusive?
Cowardice.
I had a feeling.
Her recent tactics...
If she destroyed a ship and took the crew she would be acting like any other Morgana.
If she sank ships and left crews adrift, it would just mean she was back to playing a tool for Malice again. But...
But leaving ships intact yet leaving no trace of crew? It makes no sense! What... what does she need humans for that would make the ship and cargo superfluous?
And how are they being treated? That's what has you so upset.
Ja, Kapitän. It does. I made a promise to a special little girl.
And we'll see that you keep your promise, Graf Spee. I made it with you. We'll find out what's happening to the Morganas' human prizes and bring them back.
Assuming there's anyone left to bring back...
I don't think I've seen you hug anyone before, Graf Spee.
I'm just glad to see Father Raming again, Kapitän.
The feeling is mutual, my dear. I'm glad to see you're well!
So, Father, to what do we owe this visit? You're rather far away from home.
Oh, just running an errand for an old friend...
The Secretary of State, His Eminence Cardinal Maglione is an old friend?
Actually, yes. We served in the Vatican Secretariat together during the Great War. I was moved to return to the life of a small parish priest; his calling led him on a more... political path.
Political enough to direct a combatant to port simply so we could meet with you?
The Vatican is an observer member of the League; no different than some of the Great Powers like The United States of America. His Holiness has the right to make occasional requests.
His Holiness the Pope... !
... Is aware of you, my child. He's not sure exactly what to make of you - but, yes, Pope Pius knows of you. As, unfortunately, does the Supreme Sacred Congregation of the Holy Office.
The Inquisition is interested in me?
Very.

Fields.MenuText: The Inquisition? I thought that was 400 years ago.
The Inquisition is interested in Graf Spee?
I would think they'd be more concerned with the Morganas.

Fields.DialogueText: They go back that far, but they do still exist. They're called the Supreme Sacred Congregation of the Holy Office these days and they're tasked with maintaining the purity of the Faith.
Keenly.
Oh, they are, Kapitän. Very much so. But to date no Morgana has yet claimed to be Catholic.
Then... my existence is a heresy?
In the eyes of some. It's being hotly debated. There are some very passionate canon lawyers on your side... present company included.
Still, for now I've been asked to convey to you, Fräulein, that for the time being you are forbidden to partake of any sacrament... until more is understood.
Not even absolution?
Not even absolution.
Does that apply to me? I'm not ordained, but I am this ship's captain. Graf Spee told me that I could be her, how did she put it...
Confessor.
You're a clever one, Kapitän.... I like that. What you do as a layman is your own business, of course.
And, personally, I think in this the Good Lord has already made His feelings known by bringing the two of you together.
A package?
From a certain little girl who was most insistent I bring you this. With all the disruptions to the mail of late, she didn't want to risk it getting lost.
Emily! Father, how is she doing? She's says so much in her letters but shares so little. I can't imagine life in an orphanage is easy.
By most measures she seems to be doing well. Her marks in school are exemplary, she follows instructions... the Sisters consider her a joy to have around because she makes no trouble.
No trouble? None? Uh-oh.
That's a problem?
Your knowledge doesn't cover human children, does it?
... Nein. I can count on one hand the number of times a child has been on board. Where would I have come across such a thing? Is something wrong with Emily, Kapitän?
Just a feeling... Father?
Like I said, she's doing well enough and seems content, but is also reserved and highly private. I'm told she spends her time alone when not in school or seeing to her chores.
I don't think she has any friends, and when I ask other girls about her they claim she doesn't want any. In their words, she's "prickly."
I probably make it sound worse than it is, Fraulein. It may be nothing.
I'm sorry, Father. My worry isn't due to what you just shared.
Morganas?
Again...
@BATTLE
Speaking of bringing people together...
Attention, crew! We are being raided! Get to your stations!
@BATTLE
You in here, Graf Spee? The steward says he'll be bringing dinner shortly.
Oh? I'll clear the table, then.
You still have the charts out? We can dine in the officers' mess if you'd prefer.
It's fine, Kapitän. There's nothing more I can learn by staring at them that I haven't already learned.
Which is?
*Sigh* Nothing.
Well, the least I can do is help you put them away.
You don't have to, Kapitän.
I know. I just want to.
So, I noticed the new artwork in your chapel corner. Emily, I presume?
It was in the package Father Raming brought me. It's rather crude, but for some reason I can't help but smile when I think of it.
You might call it crude, but for a nine-year-old, it's pretty good. The detail of your superstructure and turrets is good enough to tell it's you.
I suppose. Two triple turrets, one fore and one aft, is rather distinct, Kapitän.
Perhaps. Not many children her age have an eye for detail enough to catch those details. I doubt I did.
You don't give yourself credit, Kapitän!
If you say so, Graf Spee. I'll admit she still has work to do on her human figures. The three of us on your deck are horribly out of proportion, but still – she's nine.
That makes a difference?
Excuse me?
It's just... how do human children learn?
Kapitän, dinner's ready!
Red sky at night, sailor's delight.
The barometer suggests otherwise, but it is a beautiful sunset.
What brings you up to the weather deck, Kapitän?

Fields.MenuText: A lovely sunset and lovely company. Do I need another reason?
Thought I'd check on your progress with the instruments.
I looked everywhere else. I thought you would have noticed me wandering the decks.

Fields.DialogueText: Oh, my! Um... perhaps...
Now isn't exactly the best time for an inspection of my technique, Kapitän.
I'm sorry. I've been... distracted.
I can tell something has you troubled. That's why I thought I'd come calling.
The crew...
Is pensive, yes. I just happen to have a penny...
I'm not sure you want to hear my thoughts. They have nothing to do with duty or the Morganas.
If that's true, then I'll give a week's pay.
You'd be overpaying.
I'll be the judge of that, Graf Spee. Seriously, what's on your mind?
What was it like to be a child, Kapitän?
Oookaay... it looks like you win the bet. This is a conversation for somewhere less windy. I'll share what I can if you can share what it's like to be christened and fitted out.
I'd like that, Kapitän. Although we will have to make a slight detour by the bridge first. There's a skulking Morgana in the darkness ...
@BATTLE
But right now I'm not sure I'm the best company, Kapitän.
Well, that sounds like a lusty cry. How's the mother?
Commander Geirig is coming out now with the new addition.
Ah. Well, Doctor?
This is not a conversation for the decks, Kapitän. Come inside, please.
That probably says it all. Damn.
I'm sorry, Kapitän. I did the best I could.
I know you did, Doctor. Don't mind me.
He's a boy, if you're curious. And in remarkable shape given that we fished his mother out of the water.
What's remarkable is how the woman managed to hang on for long after the sinking. I wonder why Starvation left her. Graf Spee?
Starvation is a mystery to me as much as to you. I can only hope it's her own idea, and not Cowardice's methods being adopted by other Nixe.
I do too. Well, Cowardice herself couldn't have left us with a worse pickle, though.
Excuse me, Kapitän?
A baby.
Exactly.
Will both of you please stop speaking in riddles and tell me what the problem is? He's healthy, correct? He's certainly noisy enough.

Fields.MenuText: Don't knock it, Graf Spee. At this point, it would be a bad sign if he didn't have a good set of lungs on him.
Not as noisy as a call to battle stations.
Consider it "baby" for "Mayday, Mayday, Mayday," Graf Spee... and it's currently the only signal he knows.

Fields.DialogueText: I see.
... Kapitän, that still doesn't answer my question.
Hmm...
Are you are aware of how newborns get nourishment, Fräulein Graf Spee?
Oh...
@BATTLE
He'll settle when he's warm, dry and sated. ... Our problem comes from how to take care of that third one, Schiffsdame.
Right now, Schiffsdame, his distress is about being poked, prodded and cleaned up by my staff after suddenly and rudely being separated from his mother and thrust into the wide world.
The real problem comes when he starts feeling hunger and wants us to do something about it.
*ALARM*
Kapitän...
I see them!
Get ready for battle! And somebody sound the klaxon!
@BATTLE
... I was afraid of that.
Command says there's no way we can be relieved any time soon. There's at least three Morganas known to be active in the area and we're the only Belle-ship anywhere close.
What about a relief ship to retrieve the child?
Given the high Morgana activity, it would need to be escorted.
And if there was an escort available...
Exactly... she'd simply relieve us. For now we can't leave our station, or a lot more than one child could be lost.
Could we send Siegfried to safety in one of my floatplanes, then?
Not when we're so far from shore and we need all the reconnaissance we can get.
Talk is of sending someone else's spotter to us, to transport--
Wait. "Siegfried?" He's got a name already?
It was the executive officer's idea. His survival was a victory over the Morgana that left his mother to die.
Ahh.
There are many, myself included, who believe divine intervention was involved. His name also means "protection."

Fields.MenuText: Hmmm, I like it.
Well, I suppose we couldn't just keep referring to him as "the baby" forever.
Isn't the captain supposed to be involved in christening things on board a ship?

Fields.DialogueText: I do too. Still...
That was the general sense of the crew as well. Still...
I think the idea was to give him a placeholder, until his mother's next-of-kin can be reached. Is there a different name you were thinking of christening him with?
Still. Will it make a difference? I'm honestly not sure.
That's what has me worried, too.
'Siegfried' it is then.
... Like this?
That's it, Fräulein. Cradle him below your elbow and nestle his head right there... You'll have this down in no time!
A human infant is more... fragile... than I imagined.

Fields.MenuText: Given how little experience you have with this, you're coming along pretty well... from a bystander's point of view.
It would seem that babies can bring out the maternal instinct even in a ship.
I would think even we adults would seem that way to you, Graf Spee. Compared to you, we're all pretty squishy.

Fields.DialogueText: Do you really think so, Kapitän?
I've been told that not all human mothers are equal, so I suspect a tender would take to this with more ease than I.
... I'm not sure that is a flattering thing to say, Kapitän. To me, or to any human woman.
Well, Siegfried seems to be doing well enough.
I... suppose. Birgit says he reminds her of her own son when he was born. We've been collecting blankets, clean cloths for diapers...
Rubber tubing for a pacifier, too, I see. Clever.
That was Fräulein Fiedler's idea. But...
It won't last long, I know. Babies need to eat.
The galley staff do appear busy. I can't make sense of what they're brewing, though. What do babies eat when they have no mother's milk?
According to Dr. Geirig, we should find out shortly...
My curiosity will have to be satisfied later, it seems. Birgit, if you would... I will be needed soon.
@BATTLE
More like this, Schiffsdame.
You have to support his head. It'll be a few months before he can hold it up on his own.
Frau Fied... Andrea, here, take him. I'm just making a mess...
No, no, Fräulein, you're doing just fine.
But... but...
It's not your technique that has him crying, Graf Spee.
I had no better luck. He's just not taking to the Kondensmilch...
But he hated the substitute!
It's all right, Graf Spee.
Nein, Kapitän! It's not!
You're getting worked up, Fräulein. Showing your stress will just make little Siegfried even more upset.
But... but he's so hungry...

Fields.MenuText: He's a strong little guy, Graf Spee. We're not giving up yet.
Hey, chin up. We'll figure this out.
I don't blame him. I think I'd probably rather starve too, than gag down that earlier crud...

Fields.DialogueText: Some children never learn to suckle. I had a terrible time with my own son before we finally figured it out.
Some children never learn to suckle. I had a terrible time with my own son before we finally figured it out.
Some children never learn to suckle. I had a terrible time with my own son before we finally figured it out.
... Schiffsdame. He's lost his mother. If it comes to the worst... are you prepared to recognize this as God's will?
... Here, Birgit. I'm not sure what God wills for this child, but if his mother had wanted him to join her so soon, I don't think she would have held out until our arrival.
That verdammte Nix has made things stressful enough. I will ensure she adds no more.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
So how is Siegfried?
Oh...
It breaks my heart to see him so miserable, Kapitän.
I'm sorry, Graf Spee.
He's taking a little Kondensmilch but rejecting everything else. And according to the doctor, not nearly enough milk to survive until we're released from patrol.
He shared as much with me. Given the short notice, he's talking about sticking a tube down to his stomach to force feed the boy.
Before we go that far, I want to talk to you about an idea I have.
Of course.
Kapitän, you are aware that we Belles can sweat, sneeze, bleed...the more uncouth may even spit.

Fields.MenuText: Some even vomit...
... Go on...
I hope you don't think I take it for granted that you're capable of blood, sweat, and tears...

Fields.DialogueText: Please don't make light of me right now, Kapitän.
Ja. ... Er, well, Kapitän...
Nein, Kapitän, not at all! It's just... this may sound like an odd request... but...
I... have been talking more with Machinist Mate Bachmann and we have an idea.
Well, Graf Spee?
I request permission to lactate.
*ALARM*
Distress call. Freighter under Morgana attack 30 miles to the northwest.
We'll continue this later, I promise... perhaps pending a stiff drink.
@BATTLE
I'm sorry, Graf Spee. So, what's your idea?
Kapitän...
... Kapitän.
So, let me see if I get this straight... We've got a baby on board who just isn't thriving.
We're getting to the point where even if a relief plane got out to us, he wouldn't be in shape to make the trip.
... Ja, Kapitän.
And we're worlds away from a wet nurse.
That is my hypothesis, Kapitän.
I think I’ve managed to wrap my head around that much.  But, Graf Spee, milk isn’t something a woman’s body makes just because she feels like it.
Not a human woman’s body, no.  But I’m--
Very well. I'll write off on the attempt... IF you can give me assurances that battle takes priority, you won't regret it if this doesn't work, and you will let him go if it does.
Kapitän, you have my word.
@BATTLE
I came to get a progress check. Can I take the quiet around here as a good sign?
You have perfect timing. I won't say he's out of the woods yet – Siegfried has some catching up to do – but I'm more optimistic now than I was before.
Fantastic news. It sounds like Graf Spee is a natural.
Not a bit. But our Schiffsdame has three things going for her. She's the soul of patience and has experienced support for assistance.
So what's the third?
She didn't have to deliver him first.
*ALARM*
Except, scientifically speaking, lactation is a biological function... just another glandular production, like sweat and tears. And if you Belles can produce tears and sweat, why not milk.
A Belle. Yes, I'm aware.
I have, and I would have Doctor Geirig analyze a sample first to ensure it’s safety.  However, since I don’t bleed diesel fuel, I believe the risk to be low.

Fields.MenuText: Have you considered the possibility that even if you pull it off, ship’s milk might be toxic?
For someone who doesn’t claim to be human though, you’ve got some strong maternal instincts in you.

Fields.DialogueText: If you say so, Kapitän.  I’d like to think all ships are protective of the souls they carry, and the ones most open to creative solutions tend to be the most successful.

Fields.MenuText: It’s that important for you to try?

Fields.DialogueText: Ja.  If it doesn’t work, I can at least take comfort that I tried everything I could think of.
Well?
With the weather as it is, the relief plane is making good time.
And Siegfried?
Andrea has him settled.
Sounds good. I'm going to have a hard time making sure I get her back... hopefully no one tries to use a bird in hand to snatch up a seasoned Pharmacist Mate.
He'll be taken good care of until his family arrives, Graf Spee. There's no way we could keep an infant on board.
I know that, Kapitän. I also gave you my word I would let him go.
You still have that look, though. The one you get when you feel the need to confess something.
We're alone, Graf Spee. No one will hear except me, or we can wait...
Nein, Kapitän. It's just...
I'm curious. What is it like to be with child?

Fields.MenuText: I... honestly have no idea.
What makes you think I'd know?
I... have no idea how to explain it to someone who hasn't. It's like me asking what it's like to return to your hull.

Fields.DialogueText: I realize that, Kapitän. But I wasn't comfortable asking Birgit something so personal.
I suppose you're right... Doctor Geirig would probably be the better person to ask. Medically speaking, if not personally...
I suppose I can see your point, Kapitän, but I didn't think it hurt to ask.
You've given it serious thought, haven't you?
Ja.

Fields.MenuText: You Belles get more human every day. The Vatican might disagree, but I don't think you have anything to confess.
You're a warship, Fräulein. ... That said, whether such a thing could even be possible or not...
Don't forget that you've saved far more lives than any one woman could ever create.

Fields.DialogueText: You aren't the first woman to find herself musing over that question and I'm sure you won't be the last.
Thank you for understanding.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
I feel... my heart... Kapitän, my chest feels tight. I miss him so much and it’s been less than a hour.
I think I know one reason why your chest feels so tight, Graf Spee. You’re... leaking.
... So I am.
I’ll be right here if you want to go clean up.
That and find the "off" switch...
Kapitän!
Calm down, Graf Spee. What has you in such a rush?
This telegram from Father Raming! Emily ran away!

Fields.MenuText: She what!?
They're absolutely sure she's missing? I mean, there's no need for alarm if she's just late, or playing hide-and-seek...
Does it say if he has any idea why, or where she might have gone?

Fields.DialogueText: Abandoned her post! Slipped her Festmachleinen when no one was looking! Disappeared from the map!
According to this cable, they're sure of it!
What his cable says makes little sense, Kapitän.
It says she left a note to the effect that she's going after her parents. The nuns found a stash of letters... Father says he is coming to us by airplane with them.
Aren't the letters probably yours?
I would have thought so too, but the telegram suggests there's something more going on.
Kapitän, you don't suppose...
One thing at a time, Fräulein. We're operating out of port right now, so you'll see him as soon as he arrives, assuming we're not sortieing to address a Morgana.
Captain to the bridge. New orders from command.
@BATTLE
Remain calm... Now, let's start from the top. What's in the message?
There they are! Let's get them!
@BATTLE
I know you're supposed to be a fast ship, Fräulein, but I had been told that even under the best of circumstances you wouldn't be this soon.
When properly motivated, Father, Belles are known to create their own miracles. Don't ever underestimate this ship.
Ah... I simply didn't want to waste time in transit that could be spent finding out what's going on.
Then I won't waste time with pleasantries. You're correct; time is of the essence.
So what do those letters contain?
Not good news, I'm afraid. You're aware of the strange Morgana behavior around here of late? How they take only the crew and leave the ships behind?
You mean they're connected? How?
The Morganas covered their tracks well enough that it hadn't been noticed before, but in addition to other vessels, several non-manifested mail ships have been affected.
Mail? Then, you mean--
Your letters back and forth with Emily, Fräulein. It appears there's a Morgana who has intercepted your mail, and she's been inserting her own.
We only checked for what was missing, not added. ... Then we put skeleton crews on them and moved the mail along.... Dammit!
Malice. It's Malice, isn't it!
I'm no expert on your adversaries, Fräulein, but this stack of letters is from someone who worked very carefully to build trust with Emily.
You mean Emily ran away to... join Malice?
That's what we believe happened, although Emily certainly didn't know the mysterious benefactor offering her the chance to rescue her parents was a Morgana.
... Or at least, she didn't when she left.
I'll kill her!

Fields.MenuText: She has Emily, though... Would you still be able to attack her if she used her hostage as a shield?
She's not the only cruel Morgana we know, Graf Spee. Rescue should be on your mind right now, not revenge.
Let's find her first. Fast.

Fields.DialogueText: ...You're right, Kapitän. My fury won't change what she's done, and I need to focus on what's important– getting to the bottom of this.
I understand. Still, after we rescue Emily, whoever ensnared her like this will answer to me for it.
I'm in full agreement, Kapitän.
I suspect you will get your chance to confront her, Kapitän... Fräulein. Where she was helping Emily get to was never a secret - the author of the letters is challenging you to follow.
I suspect the Chinese port of Tsingtao means something to you, Fräulein.
Tsingtau? It was the home port of the East Asia Squadron, before the Great War.
We need to notify the Fleet and replenish first. She's baiting us, that's for sure, but at least we're aware of it. We'll want to bring some surprises of our own.
We most assuredly will.
My next stop is Rome - to report on this incident to the Cardinal Secretary of State. I'll ensure no one tries to interfere with your freedom to finish this.
I've lived with bureaucracy all my life. It's best to have someone in the offices making sure resources aren't redirected.
You're a very wise man.
I try to use what talents I've been given to their fullest.
... Before I leave, Kapitän, if I might have a place out of the way of your preparations, I would like to provide confession to any among your crew who desire it.
To any among my crew, you say... Do you need anything else?
A privacy curtain from the infirmary would be most welcome. It helps the shyest members of the flock to come forward if they can do so anonymously.
I see. You're free to use my mess... it's already an impromptu chapel. Graf Spee, do you think you could grab a curtain and pass along the word on the offer?
Certainly, Kapitän.
... And while you're at it, get into the queue.
But Kapitän... it would be wrong...
What would be wrong would be me withholding a sacrament to an entire ship's crew, simply because the ship is ordered to abstain.
And the beauty of an anonymous confession is that I don't know who's on the other side. Fräulein, if you would like to begin your mission with a clean slate, consider it my gift.
But Father... I thought...
Sometimes it's best not to think and instead just act. Seeing your anxiety over one little girl leaves me no doubt of your grace... not that I had any.
Rome is far away and I am here. If my blessing can help even a little, I wish to provide it.
I... don't know what to say.
Then just say "yes, Kapitän," and kindly show our guest to the mess. Meanwhile, there's work to do.
Yes, Kapitän.
But... Cowardice? This sounds like too involved a plot for her.
Her namesake was stationed there, Father. Back in the last war.
I see. So, it's personal to you, then?
I... ja. If Emily was being taken there... when may we leave?
It's going to be all right, Graf Spee.
I'm sorry, Kapitän. I'm just... frightened.

Fields.MenuText: I'm worried for her too.
You need to be able to shake that off, Graf Spee.
And leaking...

Fields.DialogueText: I'm not used to the feeling.
But this is Emily, Kapitän! I held her in my arms!
Please don't mock me, Kapitän. I know you're just trying to distract me, but now is not the time.
Be that as it may, pacing a rut into your deck isn't going to help Emily.
*Sigh* I know. I'm sorry.
Anyway, when I said it was going to be all right, I had some meat attached to the comment.
Oh?
It sounds like you've been so distracted that you missed that incoming transmission.
I guess so. What was in it?
A lot.
That's... rather surprising.
I think so too. All I can imagine is that this is Father Raming's doing. If so, the Holy See's influence in the League is a lot more than I imagined.
I'm not exactly complaining...
Yeah, I know. Maybe our luck is changing.
There she is!
Mischief? Or Emily? Here?
... No. Vanity.
Call General Quarters, then. Consider it a chance to work some anxiety off.
Jawohl!
@BATTLE
Sorry about that.
Point one. We're formally on a mission to recover Emily. It's our number one priority.
That brings me to my second piece of news. What intelligence we've been able to gather does strongly suggest that Malice is behind the mail plot. But--
I'm not seeing the luck.
But it sounds an awful lot like a different heavy cruiser was spotted in the region of Emily's disappearance.
So? Why does this matter?
Because it sounds like Mischief is the one who's actually carrying Emily. And Mischief is much less likely to hurt her just to get under our skin.
The constant harrying since we crossed into the East China Sea... she's been teasing us.
You're giving her too much credit. She was counting on us - you, really - being demoralized and ineffective. We were supposed to be dead by now.
Ja.
How are you holding up?
Captain, the search parties have returned! You were right - they picked up the trail near the old Hafenamt of the East Asia Squadron.
Did they find Emily?!
No, Miss Graf Spee. But they found this sealed envelope...
"For Admiral Graf Spee and her captain." Thank you, and good work. Have the exec call back the other search parties. We may be setting off shortly.
Aye-aye, sir!
So, what does it say?

Fields.MenuText: See for yourself. I'll consider the lock of hair the final evidence that Emily's disappearance and our Morgana with the poison pen are linked.
Brace yourself, Graf Spee.
After the introductory insults, taunts, blame for our current predicament, and some coordinates, not much.

Fields.DialogueText: ... I will remain calm, Kapitän.
... She doesn't have to. Kapitän, without a doubt, it's Malice.
She says Emily is unharmed... for now, at least. If we look to the Fleet for help, or fail to play along...
If she hurts her...
I know, Fräulein. I know.
@BATTLE
It may hard to see a silver lining, but... at least she offered proof in the form of hair. That will grow back, at least.
Agreed.
I know you've seen the damage reports.
Not what I meant.
Ja. I know.
I just... I can't think of a single reason why Emily would still be healthy. Alive, yes, because she's useful to Malice alive - assuming that Mischief is doing her bidding.
We've never had reports of Mischief indulging in the kinds of human experimentation we've seen from other Morganas. I'm not saying she's not a killer, but she's not the worst sadist of the bunch.
But physically unharmed? Sane? Well fed?
I know that's not a lot to pin your hopes on, but it's real. I don't think it's unrealistic to hope Emily's in one piece. I just don't.
... I just want her to be okay.
Me, too.
I don't know what this means for the Mischief hypothesis. I believe Malice wrote this letter, and she clearly has access to Emily's hair, but...
Be quiet! We can get them off guard!
@BATTLE
More harriers. How many Morganas has Malice managed to pull into her sick little scheme?
No idea, but I'm sure she's got to run out eventually. They're providing good reason to be in these waters, anyway.
I know the Empire of Japan has a League of Nations mandate, but the amount of red tape to let us sail here was galling. And I'm not convinced they're sharing all their intelligence.
I doubt too many Germans have seen this area since the Japanese showed up, let alone a German Belle.
That is regrettable. The Carolines were a favorite of Admiral Von Spee.
... Do you have the admiral's actual memories, Graf Spee?
Not his memories, per se, Kapitän. Just visions... images... of what he did and where he was. I don't know what was in his head so much as what he did and said, if that makes any sense.
I think it does. I just suddenly had a vision of a future ship being named after me and knowing every thought I ever had.

Fields.MenuText: It felt... disconcerting.
What a warped Belle she would have, am I right?
But I guess if that was how it went, Belles would be people reincarnated as ships rather than ships with their own unique spirits.

Fields.DialogueText: Heh. Have something to confess, Kapitän?
I'd never given that any thought, since you are still very much alive.
Ja. Besides, people aren't the only thing ships are named after. There are Belles named for places, events, qualities, natural phenomena, animals...
A rather morbid line of thought, given at any moment Malice could spring her trap. What do you suppose she has planned for us?
On Pagan Island? Given that Admiral Von Spee's fleet set out from there during the Great War, anything is possible. She's leading us for now, so we'll just have to wait and see.
I think we all have things we'd rather take to the grave, Fräulein.
Yeah, good point... that would make Nerpa the reincarnation of a seal.
Is something wrong?
Someone is broadcasting... on open frequency...
What's the message?
Before noon local time... the heir to the Empire of Austria-Hungary... Archduke Franz Ferdinand was assassinated....

Fields.MenuText: She's taking liberties with history, though. Following the path of the original Graf should send us to Truk at this point, not Pagan Island.
... I hope Samoa looks good this time of year...
And now it begins.

Fields.DialogueText: Perhaps she wants to cast me in the role of SMS Emden, and have me sail alone to the Indian Ocean.
...All of this to set me on the Admiral's path? Unglaublich.
Any idea where it's coming from?
Hmm.
Graf Spee?
I need to confer with our radio operator, but... I think I'm also hearing a nearby distress signal.
@BATTLE
...The Morganas destroyed every cable and radio station on Yap? That's a hell of a way to end a transmission...
And a devious welcome to Ponape. Based on the damage she had a lot of firepower and was indiscriminate.
Sounds like we're off to Eniwetok, unless you think she might have left any clues.
Ah... That's right! The message stopped repeating during the battle, but at its end there was an addition... See you in Bora Bora.
And Tahiti too, I'll just bet. Terrific.
We should be so lucky.
*ALARM*
She's really trying very hard to put you in mind of your namesake's career, isn't she?
*THUD*
Ugh.
That's a violent game of Patience you're playing.
That's probably an apt description of my mental state. I've lost twice already.

Fields.MenuText: Then it's probably a very good thing that you're trying to relax.
Not every game of Patience can be won, you know.
Graf Spee, there are times when you can cheat. Like when you play yourself, for instance...

Fields.DialogueText: Ja. I probably should have done this sooner.
I know, so I'm only counting the number of games that I could have won but didn't due to my own poor judgement.
I prefer to play the cards as they come, Kapitän, and analyze where I went wrong when I can go no further.
*Sigh* You heard the news, Kapitän. They were terrified of Admiral Graf Spee coming to Bora Bora.
That's why "Voykov" visited instead.
I am still impressed that you knew it would work, Kapitän. Besides the fact that Fräulein Voykov and I look nothing alike, there's a big difference between a destroyer and a Panzerschiff.
Most people aren't part of the Fleet... or get to see the latest newsreels. To a first-timer with no other warship to compare her to, a destroyer is a battleship.
For most people "Voykov" wears a white dress, has short hair, and carries a big gun. With your glasses off, you were fine.
Then I'll likely need to apologize to Fräulein Mahan if she stops around here any time soon, given "Admiral Graf Spee" has glasses, hair off her neck and carries something tube-like.
Not if Admiral Graf Spee puts the Morganas in their place for all this. Malice and her cohorts have been dictating the rules of this game for too long... what say we make them for once?
What did you have in mind?
@BATTLE
I'd rather accept the loss and and learn from my mistakes, than cheat myself of a learning experience.
I see your point.
*ALARM*
Call it – heads or tails?
Whether to go to Nuku Hiva or not?
Whether to go to Mazatlán or the Galápagos.
B-but Kapitän, the Ostasiengeschwader didn't head north.
Yes, and they weren't hounded the minute they left Tsingtao, either. Malice wants to recreate Von Spee's Pacific-spanning game of Marco Polo. Fine.
Then Malice gets to start guessing where we're bound for next.

Fields.MenuText: If you have another idea for a heading, I'm all ears, Graf Spee.
So we give Chile a break. If we're lucky, we can draw away whatever Malice has waiting for us at Coronel and Valparaiso and slip past.
I have no intention of having you run her gauntlet when we both know where she is. You don't deserve this, and neither does her hostage.

Fields.DialogueText: When you put it that way, there are so many places I'd like to avoid, to minimize the damage a fight would do.
They still may not move...but the longer they stay in one place, waiting for me, the better the chance that the Fleet can mobilize and defeat them.
Port-au-Prince, then. That's where I want to go. If she's going to have me chased like this, then I must be standing in for SMS Dresden.
So we can catch her from the north? I like it!
Natürlich.
@BATTLE
That would leave the Galápagos out.
Let me think for a minute...
Hell, the whole Pacific Ocean doesn't deserve this.
Now you're talking! The Morganas can get their Battle of Coronel – we just don't have to attend it.
*ALARM*
And, of course, it would be rude to make her wait too long... the Canal as a shortcut?
Can I help you, Kapitän?

Fields.MenuText: Sorry for interrupting. Finish your prayers and don't mind me.
Well, I have this ship, see, and she's under a lot of stress... any advice on how I can help her?
Worry beads?

Fields.DialogueText: I was just finishing, so your timing is impeccable.
Beyond making sure her diesel is always of the sweet, purified variety, and her magazines stocked with shells, I think you do a fine job maintaining this ship of yours.
Not exactly, although I suppose since I find prayer brings with it a sense of inner peace, that could be one way to look at the function of a rosary.
Taking the initiative seems to have been good for your morale.
Let me know if I'm projecting. I know it's been good for mine.
Nothing. A mother finds a way. When we meet Malice I will be the archangel Michael incarnate.
Never met the guy. But all we really need is the Admiral Graf Spee incarnate.
Kapitän...
Seriously, that thing you said about me needing you to be a "pure and uncomplicated warship?" I don't know where it came from, but it's... well, it's not what I would say.
I need you to be you. I need you to be brave and kind and thoughtful. Okay? I can't tell you how much worse this war would have been for me if you had been anything less than what you are.
Now you're just flattering me.
I'm really not trying to.
... But we should probably get back to business now.
@BATTLE
It's not just you. We were too reactive for too long. It feels like I've been managing panic ever since...
Ever since Siegfried was born, maybe?
... Ja. It does go that far back, doesn't it?
Well, if you ever find yourself considering motherhood, I think it's like that, but for decades at a time.
You need me to be a pure and uncomplicated warship right now, nicht wahr?
As opposed to...?
...So she knows we're coming.
So it would seem, from the skiff full of black roses. One for every member of my crew, by appearances.
Don't let it get to you. As soon as the coxswain's back from searching it, you can send it to Davy Jones' Locker.
This... goes beyond her symbolic display. Have you ever heard the saying that someone is "walking over your grave?"

Fields.MenuText: I can't say that I have.
That's a tad on the morbid side...
I have said that once or twice, myself.

Fields.DialogueText: It's a sense that this may be your fate, or that you're approaching fate.
Facing death is morbid, but it is what warriors do.
Then perhaps you will understand.
Since we passed Trindade, that feeling has been... growing. Maybe...
None of that, Graf Spee. Think positive. Remember.
Ja, Kapitän. I... will try. But her location...
Kapitän, she's sitting directly where the SMS Scharnhorst went down. She means to add me to my namesake's grave.
Well, then, she made a mistake bringing Emily into this. This fight's not just about us, and it's not a re-enactment of the Battle of the Falkland Islands.
We have someone to rescue. Focus on that and forget the rest.
Graf Spee?
... What am I missing?
Es tut mir Leid. We'll... have to discuss it later.
@BATTLE
Kapitän. I'm sorry I kept you waiting. I... Es tut mir Leid.
Stop. It's fine. I just want to know what's wrong. You seemed to be so much more optimistic a few days ago, but....
That was... I thought I had the answer to all this. I did not.
The idea of reliving the original Admiral's last battle is that traumatic? I'm not judging you - I can't even imagine what it's like if you can remember his death. I'm just trying to understand.
... Maximilian von Spee is remembered as a hero in Germany. And you have to understand, he's a hero to me too. I'm not his reincarnation, but I literally dream about his heroism when I sleep.
Because you're a Belle and you're named after him.
Ja.
Did you know he had children? Two sons and a daughter.
The girl I don't know so well. Most of what I know about the Admiral is ultimately part of his public record. He has some privacy even from me.
Go on.
His sons, though - they grew up in the navy. At the end, Heinrich was on Gneisenau, and Otto on Nürnberg. Them I know.
The Battle of the Falklands was... unlucky for the Admiral. He had hoped to destroy a British wireless station, but encountered superior forces. He...

Fields.MenuText: I know the story. He put up a hell of a fight.
Keep going.
It's okay. Take your time.

Fields.DialogueText: He did.
Ja.
Danke.
He tried to give his light cruisers a chance to escape, engaging the British forces with Scharnhorst and Gneisenau. And the start of the battle was... it was extraordinary.
It's in the textbooks.
Ja! He played the wind against the British, and he outmaneuvered them, and he stalled them in their tracks!
But they got him in the end. Him, two thousand and some German sailors, and his sons.
Graf Spee...
You people are so fragile, you know? I don't... I don't know what the point is of making me aware enough to understand that.
I try to have faith. I try to believe that there's a plan. But when I was a sleeping ship I didn't have to worry about someone putting a baby in my hands and making me fear for his life!
Hey. Look at me.
I can't stop looking at you! You could die! Emily could die! All you amazing people could die, and I don't know how to stop it!

Fields.MenuText: My turn now. Okay?

Fields.DialogueText: Malice made me relive the Admiral's whole voyage. You see? I got to know his crew, I got to see his sons, I got to know how good they all were - and then they just died!

Fields.MenuText: Oh, Spee. You should have said something sooner.
Look at me. I'm not going to let that happen.

Fields.DialogueText: *sniff* You have enough problems without me blubbering all over you.
Listen. I have a few things to say. First, just... thank you for your trust in me. I know that couldn't have been easy to say.
Ja. I do prefer not to come across as pathetic.
Stop.
Second - I promise you, the waiting is worse than the fight itself is going to be. When the shooting starts, you're going to be living in the moment, and it will be better.
Third, I am *not* fragile. I am your captain, and I'm telling you I'm indestructible. You are never, ever going to be rid of me.
A hundred years from now, you're going to be begging the admirals to transfer my horribly wrinkled carcass away from your bridge so you can finally have some peace.
*snert*
And they're going to say, "Nope. Nope, there's not another ship in the fleet that will put up with that officer's crap."
... How do you know how to make me feel better?
Well, that's...
*KNOCK*
Sorry, Captain. Ma'am. You're needed on the bridge...
Dammit. Enter!
@BATTLE
The signal comes and goes, Captain. I swear, we had it just a minute ago. It...
*Over the radio* ...don't think they can hear...
Is that...?
Emily? Emily, can you hear me?
*static*
*static* -äulein?
Emily, it's Graf Spee! Can you hear me?
*over the radio* Yes. But I don't know for how long...
Emily, this is Graf Spee's captain. Are you okay?
*over the radio* Mm-hm.
Emily, where are you?
*over the radio*...
Emily?
*over the radio* The bad ladies are making each other mad.
*over the radio* There was a big fight, and one of the bad ladies got hurt and went away.
I don't...
Do you know their names, Emily?
*over the radio* I don't know them all... Sometimes I can understand them, but most of the time, they're speaking a foreign language. I think one is named Mischief?
*over the radio* She said it was boring.
*over the radio* Then they all shot at each other.
Is she in the room with you?
*over the radio* She's always in the room.
*over the radio* She says... she says she's going to put me in a boat, and you and Malice can race to get me.
*over the radio* ... And then... something about shooting everyone?
*over the radio* I'm sorry! I'm sorry! This is all my fault! I didn't mean*static*
Emily? Emily, can you hear me?
*static*
Emily, if you can hear me, then please listen. This isn't your fault. We're going to find you. No one who stands in our way is going to last very long. Okay?
We'll see you soon, kid.
*STATIC*
... I'm feeling motivated again, Kapitän.
@BATTLE
I wish the visibility were better.
At least it's not Morgana mist.
If it was, she probably would've suffocated by now without a Belle's protection. Assuming she's out here at all.
She is. They all are. I can sense Malice most clearly, but... but I can feel Emily's heartbeat on the water if I listen.
What, literally?
Ja. I think so.
Damn. Remind me to remind you about this if you ever feel like you were better off as an unawoken ship.
Kapitän... can we forget that conversation ever happened? I was not at my best.

Fields.MenuText: Sure. But it's not the worst thing in the world if I know what's bothering you, is it?
You were not and you have never been anything less than perfect.
No deal. But next time I'm miserable I'll unload on you and then we'll be even.

Fields.DialogueText: Nein. It's not.
You're such a flatterer! I had no idea when we first met!
I'll hold you to that.
Listen. Before things get hectic, I just want to say...
I think she's been drugged.
Pardon?
Her heartbeat. It's steady, but so slow. When she was aboard me, it was always pounding like a hummingbird's wings.
That may be for the best. If she was alone and panicking... there's a lot of ways a scared kid could get herself into trouble out here.
What would you have done? If this had happened to you when you were a child?
We're back to that again?
I am extremely curious about you, Kapitän. I... well, you must know...
I would not have guessed the "extremely" part.
Anyway. Me as a kid?

Fields.MenuText: I can't tell you how much I wanted an adventure like this. And a rescue from a gorgeous woman? I'd still be talking about it today.
Let's just say they would've had to drug me too.
This... would actually have been pretty consistent with the rest of my childhood.

Fields.DialogueText: Um... oh, my.
That seems fair.
What?
Yeah. I've had a strange life.
... Did I miss out?
What? On childhood?
Ja.
I don't know. I'd say you turned out very well without it.
You... oh, nein.
What is it?
I know where Emily is. I know where Malice is. Kapitän, we have to get between them.
Do it. And remember, Malice isn't the Indomitable, and this isn't 1914. We can...
I love your inspirational speeches, but can you save this one for after?
Go!
@BATTLE
That's it. Malice - this incarnation of Malice, anyway - is done. You did it.
It's not done until I'm sure Emily's safe.
Point taken. But you are allowed to start feeling some relief.
That... that would be very welcome.
How's our patient?
You tell me. I haven't spoken with Doctor Geirig in hours. I can say she's sluggish.
So I'm told. But Doctor Geirig had her checked out thoroughly– other than the drugs, which hopefully didn't do any permanent damage, she looks none the worse for wear.
Assuming that being stuck alone with Mischief didn't scar her for life.
I'm not sure if I can face her again, for what I've done.
For what you've done?
Ja. Had I not continued to correspond with her--
She wouldn't have become a target for Malice?

Fields.MenuText: She was on the withdrawn side even with you as a pen pal, Graf Spee. Without you, she would've been safer, but lonelier, too.
So long as the Morganas run amok, Graf Spee, no one is truly safe.
Blame Malice and Mischief. You did everything right.

Fields.DialogueText: You're still troubled.
What will happen to her now?
Well, Fleet intelligence will definitely want to meet with her... and after that?
I don't know. I'm half tempted to ask her to stick around.
What?
I'm serious. She doesn't have any close family, she's miserable on shore, and the Morganas have already targeted her once. They know her by name.
At least here we could keep an eye on her.
And if she really wants to be a sailor and find her parents, it would give her the chance to learn the ropes.
It would give you a chance to see firsthand how a human child learns, too, since you were curious about it.
That shouldn't be a deciding factor... but it was very kind of you to think of me.
You're also allowed to say that being responsible for the well-being of a child is of no interest to you at all and I should get my head checked out.
Noted. But I wouldn't go that far.
Mine spotted to port, abaft of midships, within range.
...Ah, there it is. Danke! Target acquired!
...You aren't going to practice on that one?
Oh I will, Kapitän. Gunnery is very important, but it isn't the only thing that takes skill...
*BOOM*
I didn't know your personal float planes had bombs...
They don't, usually. I'm running some tests for Fräulein Hans Lüdemann. It's only short-term, but surprisingly satisfying.
... By the way, Kapitän, there was something you wanted to say to me before our battle with Malice, wasn't there?
Was there?
Captain to the bridge!
... A transmission for us - Sabotage was sighted by a shore observation post.
That's our cue. Join me when you're done retrieving your Arado?
Certainly.
Well, as I say, I'm only half tempted. If I can get somebody on land to guarantee she'll be safe and happy, this will probably go no further.
Anyway. How are things going out here?
Ja. I interrupted you to say that Emily had been drugged.
Ah. That... might have been for the best. It would have been a distraction when we were looking for someone in need of rescue.
We're not looking for someone in need of rescue now.
True... I was going to say that I've never had the privilege of working with someone as caring and determined and graceful as you before, and I'm grateful to have this chance.
You're being ridiculous.
You said you loved my inspirational speeches.
Uhm.
Anyway. Maybe what I was really going to say was--
Dammit.
Can you listen in on the bridge and give me a preview about what this is about?
Heh. Yes, indeed.
